Tantrums – Part 1: What’s Going On?

Jetta Jacobson, Teacher + Early Childhood Professional

Ages
2-3,
3-4
Language + Literacy
Social + Emotional

Children experience emotions just like adults, but they need support and guidance to: 1) Understand their emotions; and 2) Make choices that express themselves in healthy, productive ways. If children can’t identify and control their emotions, they can’t control their behavior.

Emotional intelligence is foundational for a healthy self-image, confidence, the development of conflict resolution skills, and the ability to learn from mistakes.

Learn

Here’s a great way to think about what is happening in your child’s brain during a tantrum. In fact, teach your kids the hand “Flip Your Lid” model. It’s a simple, physical reminder for them of what needs to happen in their brain to calm down.

Basic Concepts
  • All behavior is communication – Behavior is a way of saying something that cannot be said through words. It’s a child’s way of solving a problem they’re experiencing, expressing a thought they cannot articulate, or communicating an emotion. Before you can meaningfully address a behavior, you must investigate the underlying message it’s trying to convey. Then the parenting choices you make can help your child be a part of their own learning process, and set them up for success the next time.
  • Flight, fright, fight – Remember, when your child is in the throes of a tantrum, they’re not accessing their highest level thinking skills. They’re in “flight, fright or fight” mode. Children are biologically wired to be sensory creatures; their brains process information through the physical and reactive parts of their brain (the lower brain), not the thinking (cognitive) part of their brain (the upper brain). We have to give children the tools to recognize their reactions and to self-regulate so they can access their higher thinking skills – logic and reason. Children’s brains are still maturing.
  • Tantrums are normal – They’re a common part of childhood; they’re a learning process! When children are in a tantrum they are physically under the control of their reactive brain, flooded with cortisol and unable to be reasonable or rational. Keep your words and actions simple and brief. Rationalizing with your child at this time is futile; it’ll be hard for your child to fully comprehend what you’re saying.
  • Reflection is critical, but do it post-tantrum – When your child is calm and no longer feeling vulnerable, and when the upper brain is working again, you can reflect, process and make plans for how to do it differently next time. Teaching a child to know what is not OK is a process; it’s not easy and it doesn’t happen immediately. Always process in moments of calm and safety.

Just Remember

  • Tantrums are normal!
  • If children can’t identify and control their emotions, they can’t control their behavior.
  • Before you can meaningfully address a behavior, you must investigate the underlying message it’s trying to convey.
  • Keep your words and actions simple and brief during a tantrum.
  • Take time to reflect when your child is calm.

Now, read more on handling a tantrum.

*Note – We’ve tried our best to make our Tantrums series universal and inclusive. But understandably, parents want specific answers to their particular situation. Every child is different and needs different messages. Every parent needs to look at the part they play in the dynamic.

If a child is only throwing tantrums with one adult, then it is time to look at:
  • Why the child does not have tantrums with other adults in that child’s life?
  • How are the reactions different?
  • What does the child get out of throwing a fit with one and not the other?

Playful Learning Tools

Simple calming tools for a Helper Green Basket or Cozy Corner:

  • Calm down bubbler
  • Potpourri pouch – Filled with lavender or fragrant dried flowers
  • Mirror
  • Sensory brush for skin or hair brush
  • Sunglasses
  • Hat
  • Paper and colored pencils
  • A soft, cuddly toy
  • Headphones for music
  • Noise cancelling headphones
  • Rubik’s cube
  • Squeezy hand therapy balls
  • Sensory massage balls
  • Kaleidoscope
  • Emotion stones

Our Favorite Books on this Topic

For Younger Children

  • Grumpy Bird
  • The Feelings Book
  • Calm-Down Time

For Older Children

  • The Way I Feel
  • My Mouth is a Volcano
  • Listening to My Body
  • No More Tantrums
  • Sometimes I’m Bombaloo

For Grown-ups

  • No-Drama Discipline
  • Positive Discipline Parenting Tool Cards
  • The Emotional Life of the Toddler
  • Peaceful Parent, Happy Kids
Share Favorite Print

What are your favorite resources to get smart on this topic? Tell us!

Jetta Jacobson, Teacher + Early Childhood Professional

Jetta Jacobson holds a M.A. and teaching credential in Early Childhood Special Education from San Francisco State University. She taught in a fully inclusive preschool for 20 years and now shares her knowledge and experiences as an Instructional Coach for San Francisco Unified School District. Jetta also teaches at San Francisco State University.
